question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
Our family is planning / a trip to Europe next summer / where we should visit several famous / landmarks and enjoy local cuisine.

(SSC CGL 2024 T-1 : 10-Sep Shift 2)
option_1: landmarks and enjoy local cuisine
option_2: a trip to Europe next summer
option_3: where we should visit several famous
solution:
Correct Answer: - where we should visit several famous

Explanation:

The phrase "where we should visit several famous" contains a grammatical error. The word "where" is used incorrectly here as it suggests a place, but the sentence is intended to talk about what the family is planning to do during the trip. A correct structure would be: "where we will visit several famous landmarks" or "where we plan to visit several famous landmarks.

question:
The following sentence has been divided into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
My sister, Juliet, / got married / as her / was 23.

(SSC CGL 2024 T-1 : 10-Sep Shift 3)
solution:
Correct Answer: - as her

Explanation:
The phrase "as her" is incorrect because it does not fit grammatically in the sentence. The correct expression should be "when she was 23," which indicates the time when her sister got married.

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
No sooner did / the child start crying / then the mother / hugged him.

(SSC CGL 2021 T-1 : 11 Apr S3 (4 to 5 PM))
solution:
Explanation:

The error lies in the use of ‚Äúthen‚Äù.
When using the correlative expression ‚ÄúNo sooner‚Ä¶ than‚Äù, the correct word is ‚Äúthan,‚Äù not ‚Äúthen.‚Äù

  • No sooner‚Ä¶ than is the correct structure used to describe two actions that happen in quick succession.

Part of Speech with the Error:

Conjunction ‚Äî incorrect use of ‚Äúthen‚Äù instead of ‚Äúthan‚Äù

‚úîÔ∏è Correct Sentence:

No sooner did the child start crying than the mother hugged him.

‚úÖ Therefore, the segment with the grammatical error is: then the mother.

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
My daughter was / invited to lunch / hosted by the Governor / at his residence.

(SSC MTS 2023 : 14_Sept_Shift-2)
solution:
The sentence "My daughter was invited to lunch hosted by the Governor at his residence." contains a grammatical error in the segment "invited to lunch".

The error is due to the lack of clarity regarding who is hosting the lunch. The phrase "invited to lunch hosted by the Governor" suggests that "lunch" is doing the hosting, which is not logical. To correct this, we need to include a relative pronoun to make it clear that the Governor is the one hosting the lunch.

The correct segment should be: "invited to lunch which was hosted by the Governor".

question:
The sentence below has been divided into three parts. Select the part of the sentence that has an error. If the sentence has no error, select the option 'No Error'.
I don't know the reason why he/ has said all this yet it/ puts him in a bad light.

(IB ACIO 2023 T-1 : 17 Jan S1)
option_1: has said all this yet it
option_3: puts him in a bad light.
option_4: I don't know the reason why he
solution:
Error Explanation:

üî¥ Error Type: Conjunction misuse + sentence boundary/punctuation

üìö Grammar Rule:

When two independent clauses are connected with a coordinating conjunction like "yet", a comma is required before "yet".

üß± The two independent clauses here are:

  • He has said all this

  • It puts him in a bad light

They are joined by ‚Äúyet‚Äù without a comma, which violates punctuation rules for compound sentences.

‚ùå Incorrect:

"He has said all this yet it puts him..."

‚úÖ Correct:

"He has said all this, yet it puts him..."

üìù Summary:

  • Error in Part B: "has said all this yet it"

  • Missing comma before ‚Äúyet‚Äù

  • Two independent clauses are joined without correct punctuation.

question:
The sentence below has been divided into three parts. Select the part of the sentence that has an error. If the sentence has no error, select the option 'No Error'.
She decided to take a break/ from work, while she needed/ some time to recharge and rejuvenate.

(IB ACIO 2023 T-1 : 17 Jan S3)
option_1: She decided to take a break
option_2: from work, while she needed
option_3: some time to recharge and rejuvenate.
solution:
Explanation:

  • "from work, while she needed" is incorrect ‚ùå.
    After "take a break from work", we shouldn't use "while" here. It should be "because she needed" or "as she needed" (since she needed).

  • "She decided to take a break" (no error) ‚úÖ

  • "some time to recharge and rejuvenate." (no error) ‚úÖ

So, the error is in from work, while she needed.

question:
The sentence below has been divided into three parts. Select the part of the sentence that has an error. If the sentence has no error, select the option 'No Error'.
The museum was built in 1972, although/ the chief's home and store (the museum's main attractions)/ remained closed because for their fragility.

(IB ACIO 2023 T-1 : 17 Jan S4)
option_1: remained closed because for their fragility.
option_3: The museum was built in 1972, although
option_4: the chief's home and store (the museum's main attractions)
solution:
Explanation:
The phrase "because for their fragility" is incorrect. It should be either "because of their fragility" or "for their fragility," but not both "because for."

  • ‚ÄúThe museum was built in 1972, although‚Äù

  • ‚Äúthe chief's home and store (the museum's main attractions)‚Äù

  • ‚ÄúNo error‚Äù

So, the error is in remained closed because for their fragility.

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them contains an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options.
Lalitha will go / to sister‚Äôs house / in Mumbai / this summer.

(SSC CGL 2020 T-1 : 18 August Shift 1 (9 to 10 AM))
solution:
Correct Answer: to sister‚Äôs house

Solution:
The phrase "to sister‚Äôs house" is incorrect because it omits the possessive determiner.
It should be: "to her sister‚Äôs house" to indicate whose sister is being referred to.

Correct sentence:
"Lalitha will go to her sister‚Äôs house in Mumbai this summer."

Other parts are grammatically correct and need no change.

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them contains an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options.
No sooner did Priya / get her report card / when she started jumping / with joy.

(SSC CGL 2020 T-1 : 18 August Shift 2 (12 to 1 PM))
solution:
Correct Answer: when she started jumping

Solution:
The error lies in the use of "when" after "No sooner".
The correct correlative pair is:
"No sooner... than", not "No sooner... when".

So, the sentence should be:
"No sooner did Priya get her report card than she started jumping with joy."

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don‚Äôt find any error, mark ‚ÄòNo error‚Äô as your answer.
No sooner he was / brought to the hospital / than he began panting heavily.

(SSC Steno 2022 : 18 Nov S-1)
option_3: than he began panting heavily
solution:
Answer: (a) No sooner he was

Explanation:
The phrase "No sooner" is followed by inversion in the correct sentence structure. This means the auxiliary verb should come before the subject, not after.

Correct structure:
No sooner was he brought to the hospital than he began panting heavily.

Here, "was he" (inversion) is correct, but the given sentence uses "he was", which is incorrect.

Other parts of the sentence are correct.

Hence, the error is in "No sooner he was".

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don‚Äôt find any error, mark ‚ÄòNo error‚Äô as your answer.
Not only will he take admission here / but also he will stay / in the hostel.

(SSC Steno 2022 : 18 Nov S-2)
option_1: but also he will stay
option_4: Not only will he take admission here
solution:
Correct Answer:but also he will stay
Explanation:
 The correlative conjunction ‚ÄúNot only... but also...‚Äù should maintain parallel structure.
 In the first part: "Not only will he take admission here", the auxiliary verb "will" comes before the subject "he" (inversion).
 To maintain parallelism, the second part should also follow the same structure: "but also will he stay" instead of "but also he will stay."

Correct sentence:Not only will he take admission here, but also will he stay in the hostel.

question:
Identify the segment in the sentence which contains the grammatical error.
Alex picked up the boxes quite easily even they were heavy.

(SSC CGL 2021 T-1 : 20 Apr S1 (9 to 10 AM))
solution:
Explanation:

Correct Answer: even they were heavy

üîç What‚Äôs the grammatical issue?

  • Error Type: Subordinating conjunction misuse

  • Part of speech affected: Conjunction ("even") and clause structure

üìò Rule:

The conjunction ‚Äúeven‚Äù alone is not used to introduce a clause.
The correct form here is ‚Äúeven though‚Äù, which means despite the fact that.

üîÅ Correct Sentence:

"Alex picked up the boxes quite easily even though they were heavy."

‚ùå Evaluation of Other Segments:

  • Alex picked up ‚Äì ‚úÖ Correct subject + past verb

  • the boxes ‚Äì ‚úÖ Correct object

  • quite easily ‚Äì ‚úÖ Correct adverb phrase

  • even they were heavy ‚Äì ‚ùå ‚ùå
    ‚úñ Incorrect use of ‚Äúeven‚Äù as a connector
    ‚úñ Should be ‚Äúeven though they were heavy‚Äù

üü¢ So, the segment with the grammatical error is: ‚Äúeven they were heavy‚Äù,which should be corrected to ‚Äúeven though they were heavy.‚Äù

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain a grammatical error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don‚Äôt find any error, mark ‚ÄòNo error‚Äô as your answer.
They had hardly completed / half of the work / than the boss called them.

(SSC CGL 2021 T-1 : 20 Apr S3 (4 to 5 PM))
option_4: than the boss called them
solution:
Explanation:

Step-by-step explanation:

This sentence is trying to express two actions happening in quick succession:

Hardly had they completed half the work when the boss called them.

üîπ Rule Involved:

Certain adverbs like hardly, scarcely, no sooner are used in inversion + correlative pairs:

  • Hardly / Scarcely ‚Üí always followed by when, not than

  • No sooner ‚Üí followed by than

üîπ So, the structure should be:

Hardly had they completed... when... ‚úÖ
‚ùå Hardly... than... is grammatically wrong

üîç Error Found:

"than the boss called them" ‚ùå
This is incorrect because "hardly" must be followed by "when", not "than"

‚úÖ Correct sentence:

They had hardly completed half of the work when the boss called them.

‚úÖ Final Answer:

D. than the boss called them

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them contains an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options.
It is misleading / to imagine that / computers can think / same like human beings.

(SSC CGL 2020 T-1 : 23 August Shift 3 (3 to 4 PM))
solution:
Answer: same like human beings
Solution:
‚Ä¢ The phrase "same like human beings" is grammatically incorrect.
‚Ä¢ In English, we do not use ‚Äúsame‚Äù and ‚Äúlike‚Äù together in this way. The correct expressions are:
 ‚Äì ‚Äúlike human beings‚Äù
 ‚Äì ‚Äúthe same as human beings‚Äù
‚Ä¢ Therefore, to correct the sentence, we can either say:
 ‚Üí "computers can think like human beings" ‚úÖ
 or
 ‚Üí "computers can think the same as human beings" ‚úÖ

Correct sentence:
"It is misleading to imagine that computers can think like human beings."

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
If you live / in a foreign country, / you should / try and learn language.

(SSC SP Ph-11 : 30 June Shift-1 )
solution:
The segment that contains a grammatical error is: try and learn language

The error lies in the segment "try and learn language." The correct phrase should be "try to learn the language." Using "try to" is grammatically correct, while "try and" is considered colloquial.

The corrected sentence should be: If you live in a foreign country, you should try to learn the language.

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
India‚Äôs coastline stretches / for over 7,500 kilometres, / to offer a plethora of / must visit beaches and coastal destinations.

(SSC CPO 2024 T-2 (8 Mar))
option_1: must visit beaches and coastal destinations.
option_3: to offer a plethora of
solution:
The error lies in the segment: "to offer a plethora of".

  • The verb "stretches" does not logically or grammatically connect with "to offer" in this context.

  • The phrase should be "and offers a plethora of" instead of "to offer a plethora of" for proper parallel structure and meaning.

Correct sentence:
India‚Äôs coastline stretches for over 7,500 kilometres and offers a plethora of must-visit beaches and coastal destinations.

question:
Parts of the given sentence have been given as options. One of them may contain a grammatical error. Select the option that has the error. If there is no error, select ‚ÄòNo error‚Äô.
We cannot postpone discussion on this issue although it is urgent.

(SSC CPO 2023 T-2)
solution:
Solution:
Option C: "although it is urgent." contains a logical and grammatical error in the context of the sentence.

The sentence says:
"We cannot postpone discussion on this issue although it is urgent."

This creates confusion because:

  • "Although" is used to show contrast.

  • Here, the sentence implies: "We are not postponing it, even though it is urgent."

  • That is illogical, because urgency is usually a reason to not postpone, not to do the opposite.

So, the correct connector should be "because" instead of "although", to clearly express the intended meaning:
"We cannot postpone discussion on this issue because it is urgent."

Thus, Option C is incorrect due to inappropriate use of "although."

question:
Identify the segment in the sentence which contains a grammatical error.
Hold my hand lest you should not get lost in the huge crowd at the fair.

(SSC CPO 2023 T-2)
option_1: get lost in the huge
solution:
Solution:
The error lies in the segment "lest you should not".

"Lest" is a conjunction that means "for fear that" or "to avoid the risk of". It already carries a negative meaning, so adding "not" after it creates a double negative, which is grammatically incorrect.

Correct usage:
"lest you should get lost" (not "lest you should not get lost")

Correct sentence:
"Hold my hand lest you should get lost in the huge crowd at the fair."

Option A: get lost in the huge ‚Äì correct
Option B: lest you should not ‚Äì ‚ùå incorrect (double negative)
Option C: crowd at the fair ‚Äì correct
Option D: Hold my hand ‚Äì correct

Answer: Option B (lest you should not).

question:
Parts of the given sentence have been given as options. One of them may contain a grammatical error. Select the option that has the error. If there is no error, select ‚ÄòNo error‚Äô.
I will definitely accept the responsibility while the time comes.

(SSC CPO 2023 T-2)
solution:
Solution:
The error lies in the segment "while the time comes."

Explanation:

  • The phrase "while the time comes" is grammatically incorrect.

  • The correct expression is "when the time comes."

  • "When" refers to a specific point in time, which fits here.

  • "While" refers to a duration of time, which is not appropriate in this context.

Correct sentence:
"I will definitely accept the responsibility when the time comes."

Option A: the responsibility ‚Äì ‚úî correct
Option B: I will definitely accept ‚Äì ‚úî correct
Option C: while the time comes. ‚Äì ‚ùå incorrect phrase
Option D: No error ‚Äì ‚ùå incorrect

Answer: Option C (while the time comes.).

question:
Parts of the following sentence have been given as options. Select the option that contains an error.
Apart with eco-tourism activities and jungle safaris, the Pench Tiger Reserve is gearing up to introduce stargazing experiences for tourists.

(SSC CPO 2024 T-2 (30 April))
option_1: Apart with eco-tourism activities and jungle safaris
option_4: the Pench Tiger Reserve is gearing up
solution:
Explanation:

The phrase "Apart with" is grammatically incorrect. The correct phrase is:

  • "Apart from" ‚Äì which means "in addition to" or "besides".

So, the correct sentence should be:
"Apart from eco-tourism activities and jungle safaris, the Pench Tiger Reserve is gearing up to introduce stargazing experiences for tourists."

Correct Usage:

  • ‚ùå Apart with eco-tourism...

  • ‚úÖ Apart from eco-tourism...

Hence, option 1 contains the grammatical error.

question:
The following sentence has been divided into three segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error. If you don‚Äôt find any error, select ‚ÄòNo error‚Äô as your answer.
It was possible to achieve anything, / if one has the grit and determination / to keep going.

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (11-July Shift 3))
option_3: if one has the grit and determination
option_4: It was possible to achieve anything,
solution:
Correct Answer: It was possible to achieve anything,

Part of Speech of Corrected Part:

  • was (verb, past tense of "is")

Explanation:
The error in the sentence is in the first segment: "It was possible to achieve anything," because the rest of the sentence uses the present tense "if one has the grit and determination."

To maintain tense consistency, this part should be in the present tense, as the sentence expresses a general truth rather than a past event.

Correct sentence:
"It is possible to achieve anything if one has the grit and determination to keep going."

Therefore, the segment "It was possible to achieve anything," is incorrect because of the tense mismatch and should be replaced with the present tense "It is possible to achieve anything,".

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don‚Äôt find any error, mark ‚ÄòNo error‚Äô as your answer.
It is a common perception / that the rich sometimes / despise poor.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.15_14-Oct_Shift-1)
option_1: It is a common perception
solution:
Correct Answer: despise poor.

Explanation:

  • The phrase "despise poor" is incorrect because in English, when referring to groups like "the rich" or "the poor," we must include "the" before the adjective when it acts as a noun.

  • ‚úÖ Correct phrase: "despise the poor"

So, the corrected sentence is:
"It is a common perception that the rich sometimes despise the poor."

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don‚Äôt find any error, mark ‚ÄòNo error‚Äô as your answer.
A man who has been accused of fraud / in an earlier job, he will never be / welcome in any other organisation.

(SSC CHSL 2023 T-2 (10 Jan))
option_2: welcome in any other organisation
option_3: A man who has been accused of fraud
option_4: in an earlier job, he will never be
solution:
The part that contains the error is: in an earlier job, he will never be

The corrected sentence would be: A man who has been accused of fraud in an earlier job will never be welcome in any other organization.

By removing the comma and he after "in an earlier job," we connect the clauses more naturally, resulting in a clearer and grammatically correct sentence.
